text: when we first visited Viktor in 2000 we
were in Colorado shooting an entirely
different project and someone who knew
Victor said to us guys I I just want to
drive you up to this rather unusual town
I have a feeling it would be of interest
to you and she was most definitely right
the first time we were there we saw
almost nobody
very few people it was in the middle of
winter and it was a very strange and
slightly unnerving experience it had
this quirky atmosphere that was entirely
its own it felt as though it had forged
its own unique timeline that was neither
of the past of the present it was just
running on its own frequency completely
separate from much of the rest of the
world the fact that it has an antique
shaft is an irony itself isn't it
because it's the whole place isn't it
well absolutely I mean that most of
these buildings date from the 1890s from
the Colorado gold rush there's a boom
and bust mentality associated with that
and as the gold slowly dried up it the
town with it somewhat but the character
the imprint of the people who'd forged
them this town who was very evident the
population used to be about 18,000 it's
now about 450 but people are actively
moving back there
you haven't photographed the people well
we think we kind of have actually the
place is quite mysterious and we made a
very deliberate decision once we decided
we were going to turn this into a book
that we would forego showing the
residents but we would show both past
and present residents through their
imprint on the landscape and the
building's so we think we've actually
found a great deal about them without
actually overtly showing their physical
presence
